entry.title: Revert "Get rid of RunUntilIdle in tests"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 4239a13e4bbf1e7cf1f5e40d89b2d5bfec4cd4c7.



Reason for revert: Chained to a culprit cl crrev.com/c/5201547



Original change's description:

> Get rid of RunUntilIdle in tests

>

> We need to make sure delete-on-thread happens before test fixture

> completes, when the respective object is a mock (test storage or report

> queue producer). In prod code delete-on-thread is necessary, while in

> tests it is assigned to the current task runner, and so instead of

> posting the deletion task and waiting, we can just use std::unique_ptr and thus release and delete the mock object on the main thread.

>

> After that RunUntilIdle becomes unnecessary - the tests succeed without

> it (removal is done in the tests that were recently modified; now they

> are reverted back, but there might be more tests that can be cleaned up

> this way).

>

> Bug: b:314195198

> Change-Id: I361f040820baddd939fdd92794d3b37685d7cceb

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5230347

> Commit-Queue: Leonid Baraz

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1252113}

entry.title: SQL: make wrapped VFS the default VFS
entry.content:
//sql uses a wrapper around the default VFS to accomplish certain

custom, OS-specific tasks (see vfs_wrapper.h). This wrapper is used

in `sql::Database::Open()` but is not used in other contexts such as

`sql::Database::Recover()` or `sql::Database::Delete()`.



This change makes that wrapper the default VFS so it's used

automatically for all SQLite library calls that don't specify a VFS

instead of just sqlite3_open_v2.

entry.title: [MediaFoundation] Uncompressed Audio return MF_E_TOPO_CODEC_NOT_FOUND
entry.content:
OS: Win



When the uncompressed audio was loaded, the default audio type

calculated bits per sample, block alignment, and average bytes

per second. The fix is to correctly calculate the bits per

sample by using bytes per channel instead of bytes per frame.

Also setting block alignment as bytes per frame as well as

simplifying average bytes per second calculation.





Bug: 1521636

entry.title: Skip scanning timeout glitches
entry.content:
A recent change added a small grace period before reporting an output

stream as silent. This avoids tabs from being considered silent after a

single glitch, and should lower the chance of a tab's priority being

downgraded due to silence.



This CL adds a complementary approach: avoid feeding glitches (which are

always zero'ed) into the AudioPowerMonitor, to exclude them from the

silence detection algorithm.



Both approaches are useful and complementary:

- The grace period prevents intentionally zero'ed audio data (e.g. from

a "gate" effect on a microphone input) from changing the tab's silence

state.

- Not using glitches to measure audio power levels makes for more accurate

measurements.



Bug: 1494390

Change-Id: I87e26c6cda7ee9c1dae0e73d0c862147deaccd3b

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5238422

Commit-Queue: Thomas Guilbert

Reviewed-by: Dale Curtis

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1252413}

entry.title: [Quick Delete] Add the wipe animation on the Tab Grid
entry.content:
This change creates a QuickDeleteAnimationGradientDrawable class that

will be responsible for creating the gradient drawable for Quick

Delete's wipe animation as well as the animator that runs on the

drawable.

It will also be used in a follow-up to create the fade animation.

entry.title: [SysUi download integration] Create a progress mojo type
entry.content:
This CL creates a new mojo type called DownloadProgress that

encapsulates the data related to download progress. Ash clients

render the download progress using the values cached by

DownloadProgress.



After this CL, crosapi::mojom::DownloadStatus uses this new type

instead of caching the received bytes count and the total bytes count.



In addition, DownloadProgress caches two additional attributes:



1. loop, indicating whether the progress should be represented as

infinitely looping.



2. visible, indicating whether the progress should be visually

represented.



This CL should not bring any noticeable UI changes.



Bug: b/319714839,b/319714763

entry.title: Reapply "Reland "webauthn: add EnclaveManager""
entry.content:
Landed in bb39fe0dd8f71795882de57f6ec4d0027528a7da but collided with a

change to Rust GN and we mutually broke each other.



Landed accidentally again because the CQ surprised me by not running and

I reverted that.



Third time was reverted because it broke the MSAN bots. But the MSAN

errors were "impossible". It turns out that Rust code isn't compatibly

built for MSAN and this is known (crbug.com/1369167). But when calling

C++ from Rust, the C++ reports lots of false uninitialized memory errors

because the Rust code isn't managing the shadowing in the same way.



This is difficult to address because:

* You can't ignore MSAN errors because that's controlled by a compiler

flag (`-fsanitize-recover=memory`) and Chromium doesn't set it.

* You can't reasonably suppress the failures because that would be

very fragile: any changes to either the C++ or Rust wrapping code

are likely to change where the false positives are happening.



Thus the tests have to be disabled when running under MSAN.



Change-Id: I6247d1d6c3b2b7da2241cd6a0e1a9eab244cacdc

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5237733

entry.title: [DTC] Use TabObscuringHandler to block transition
entry.content:
When tab strip transition happens when a scrim overs only the portion under the toolbar, there'll be a gap / overlap between the scrim to the toolbar. For those cases, tab strip transition should be blocked.



TabObscuringHandler is used by several other component to indicate the tab content is blocked by some other UI e.g. TabModalDialog. This CL makes TabStripTransitionCoordinator listen to that signal to decide whether to kick off an transition.



This CL also changed the timing when tab modal dialog calls #unobscur, from as soon as the dialog is dismissed, to until the exit animation is completed. This aligns with what's being done in the ScrimMediator i.e. only trigger visibility callback once scrim has alpha=0.



Bug: 1519696

entry.title: blink: change order of nodes appended in SetContentFromDOMParser
entry.content:
Prior to this change the order of appending is

head to html

body to html

html to document



This changes order to

head to html

html to document

body to html



Changing to this order means the newly added nodes only get one

InsertedInto() (when added to body) vs two before (one when body

added to html and the second when html added to document).

entry.title: Skip risk-based auth when card is expired
entry.content:
When FPAN risk-based authentication is enabled, if a user retrieves a

FPAN, now the client will fire a risk-based auth and then the server

decide challenge is required. And then user can start the expiry date

fix flow.

Instead, we want to skip the risk-based authentication and make user to

start the expiry date fix flow directly.



Before:

https://screencast.googleplex.com/cast/NTA2MzQwMzc1NTI3NDI0MHwyNDYzODcxYi1mNA



After:

https://screencast.googleplex.com/cast/NTYyNzY4MTU3NTAxMDMwNHwwMjExYjY2Zi0wNQ

entry.title: [omnibox] Fix crash for HISTORY_KEYWORD and CLIPBOARD_TEXT shortcuts
entry.content:
HISTORY_KEYWORD:



If the user creates a keyword without '%s', and types the keyword into

the omnibox, we show a HISTORY_KEYWORD match. These are weird because

- They don't seem useful

- They're considered non-searches

- Yet they have a `keyword`, `from_keyword = true`, and `transition =

PAGE_TRANSITION_KEYWORD`; i.e. they look like normal keyword

suggestions.



This breaks a DCHECK that expects only and all searches to have

keywords.



This CL fixes it by removing the keyword fields form HISTORY_KEYWORD

matches.







CLIPBOARD_TEXT:



Similarly, CLIPBOARD_TEXT also crash at the same DCHECK. They have

keywords since they search the default DSE, but aren't considered search

suggestions on iOS because of some test failures. So this CL exempts iOS

from the DCHECK.





Bug: 1516053, 1470185

entry.title: [omnibox][keyword] Revitalize autocompleted keyword providr
entry.content:
The keyword provider has the useful ability to autocomplete keywords.



E.g., if the user types 'youtu query', it can suggest a youtube search

even though the input isn't in keyword mode. It can prefix autocomplete

the 1st input term to keywords.



These autocompleted keyword suggestions are scored 450, making them

almost never appear.



This CL scores them according to a finch param instead, probably

something like 900.



This CL also allows autocompleting complete keywords; e.g. 'youtube.com

query'. Previously, the keyword provider assumed the search provider

would handle complete keywords; but the search provider doesn't (or no

longer does; perhaps it did at some point).



Both changes are guarded by a `kVitalizeAutocompletedKeywords` feature.



Bug: 1521315

Change-Id: I7a2a0356894e871e7697c86cb5fa631514001182

entry.content:
The scale factor is used in two places, both of which adjusts it in the

same way using the text item's scale factor. Given the limited scope of

this scale factor, the final scale factor can be resolved when set.



This allows to reduce the dependencies of TextPainter's

PaintDecorationsExceptLineThrough() and

PaintDecorationsOnlyLineThrough() methods by removing the FragmentItem

argument. For the former, pass a TextDecorationOffset instead.

entry.title: [wpt-exporter] Tighten GraphQL response validation

Follow-up to https://crrev.com/c/5235095:

* The speculative fix worked (e.g., [0]), so remove the debug log.

* Bad GraphQL requests can still return HTTP 200, so the GraphQL client

should actually inspect the response payload [1] for the presence of

an "errors" list (defined by the GraphQL spec).

state.

entry.title: Replace commit_by_year.sh with a python implementation
entry.content:
In addition to being MUCH faster, this also addresses a number of flaws

in the analysis. First, I've trimmed the set of repos to ones that are

really core to Chromium and have supporting Chromium as a major goal.

For example, tflite has a lot of Google commits but isn't really a core

part of Chromium and has many other uses. The VP8 and WebM codecs are

actively maintained with Chromium as a major use case, while I don't

think that's quite true for JPEG and GIF. I've done my best at this,

but I've probably made some mistakes.



Secondly, it was possible for the Chromium repository to be processed

more than once when a provided directory didn't actually represent a

new git repo. Eg. native_client is often an empty directory. I added

protection against this.



I've also updated the output to be just a single CSV file and included

the year and repo name as columns. This enables richer processing

such as using a pivot table in google sheets.



Output can be seen at https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1xT5UFlow-7KGT_oBwZobsDqmc4RAvRFcVLkCy4A7lmo/edit. Despite the fixes, the overall picture painted by the graphs is shockingly the same as what we presented at BlinkOn.

entry.title: Reland "[Autofill] Simplify ContentAutofillDriver initialization"
entry.content:
This is a reland of commit 3b90869541da848d1791a4ca8b44bc0fd4af8347



The CL did not cause the breakage. The tests seem to be

failing quite consistently on ci/mac12-arm64-rel-tests. The

first failure [1] does include the reverted CL, but the

failures continue after the revert [2].



I suspect [3] is the culprit.



[1] https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/mac12-arm64-rel-tests/18253/blamelist

[2] https://ci.chromium.org/ui/p/chromium/builders/ci/mac12-arm64-rel-tests/18262/blamelist

[3] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5224247



Original change's description:

> [Autofill] Simplify ContentAutofillDriver initialization

>

> The DriverInitHooks have two jobs:

> (1) create a {Browser,Android}AutofillManager;

> (2) call some setters on AutofillAgent.

>

> Since the introduction of ContentAutofillClient, the DriverInitHook

> can be conveniently turned into a member function of the client.

>

> This CL introduces *two* new methods in CAC:

> (1) CreateManager(), to be called by CAD's constructor.

> (2) InitAgent(), to be called by the CAD factory.

>

> The point in time they're called is important:

> - CreateManager() is called before OnContentAutofillDriverCreated(),

> which is necessary for TestAutofillManagerInjector;

> - InitAgent() is called after OnContentAutofillDriverCreated(),

> which avoids trouble with double binding mojo remotes when

> TestAutofillDriverInjector creates a new driver.

>

> Alternatives I considered are:

> - Calling CreateManager() from the factory. This would avoid the

> potential problem of the manager calling into the driver during

> the driver's construction. Rejected because this requires

> CAD::set_autofill_manager(), and since driver and manager

> have to point to each other, there will always be some kind of

> chicken-egg problem.

> - Calling InitAgent() from CAD's constructor. Rejected because

> - tests that mock an AutofillAgent would attempt to bind *two*

> remotes, which isn't allowed;

> - unbinding and rebinding remotes

> - makes writing tests harder;

> - seems not to work for the renderer -> browser remote.

> - Calling CreateManager() and InitAgent() or only InitAgent() from

> a virtual CAD::Init() function, which is be called by the CAD

> factory. Tests would override Init() and only call CreateDriver(),

> not InitAgent(). Rejected because that'd make writing tests harder.

>

> The DriverInitHook model worked similarly, but it probably worked

> out of luck: the DriverInitHooks didn't actually call

> GetAutofillAgent() in most tests, which happened to avoid the

> double bind in all relevant tests.

>

> Bug: 1200511

> Change-Id: I339a8b0e7531a76395e5e50dba16f77e3385f56a

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5224630

> Reviewed-by: Jan Keitel

> Commit-Queue: Christoph Schwering

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1252040}



Bug: 1200511

Change-Id: Ib923916a0bd31c920ee089569584c1728289731d

entry.title: WebUI: Enforce querySelector<Type>() pattern via ESLint, part 5 (last)
entry.content:
A common misuse of querySelector/querySelectorAll is to use a type cast,

like

this.shadowRoot.querySelector(...) as Type



instead of leveraging the type parameter, like

this.shadowRoot.querySelector(...)



In this part enabling an ESLint check leveraging the

'no-restricted-syntax' rule, that catches such patterns, with an error

as follows:



"Don't use 'querySelector(...) as Type'. Use the type parameter,

'querySelector(...)' instead"



All violations across the codebase, should have been fixed or

suppressed in previous CLs.



Bug: 1521107

entry.title: Re-enable HeapProfilerController tests on iOS
entry.content:
HeapProfilerController schedules a snapshot with a BEST_EFFORT task.

On iOS, when the test advances the mock clock by two days, the

BEST_EFFORT task doesn't run until the end of the period, meaning a

task that should be delayed half an hour runs after two days instead. This doesn't leave time for tasks posted after the BEST_EFFORT task

to run before the test ends.



Instead, run the TaskEnvironment loop until the BEST_EFFORT task and

all followups run.



Also adds an expectation to StartHeapProfiling so that each test

checks that profiling is enabled when expected.





Bug: 1302007

Change-Id: I32a2975e6e477793bf553f2177f1c73fd0de445f

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5234370

entry.title: Delay JankTrackerImpl for 3 seconds to prevent impacting start up.
entry.content:
Currently we're seeing a 2% drop in recorded Android start ups and a

.4% increase in start up time on the 50p for stable.



This CL would address this by moving this into a separate task and only

enabling it once we've passed the 95th percentile of start up (and in a

task that could be delayed further if Chrome decides to).



There is no evidence of increased crashes so the only theory is since this is a bit heavy weight with a whole thread creation we should wait until startup has finished.

entry.title: Add DumpWithoutCrashing to debug renderer hangs
entry.content:
This CL is adding DumpWithoutCrashing to collect dumps of a suspected

root cause of renderer hangs.



We suspect the issue is related to WaitableEvent::TimedWaitImpl(...) which will infinite loop if WaitForSingleObject(...) is returning one

of the unhandled results. The goal of this CL is to collect minidumps

to validate the current hypothesis of an infinite loop.



This is currently hanging at the start of the HangWatcher when

trying to create the first simple thread. We expect to replace these

hangs by clean process shutdown.



Unfortunately, the cause of these error code is still a mystery.



R=gab@chromium.org

CC=​​​grt@chromium.org

entry.title: [SAA] Extending Storage Access API to omit unpartitioned cookies
entry.content:
The current Storage Access API requires that unpartitioned cookie access

is granted if any unpartitioned storage access is needed. This forces

unpartitioned cookies to be included in network requests which may not

need them, having impacts on network performance and security. Before

the extension ships, we have a chance to fix this behavior without a

compatibility break.



Design Doc:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/19qCGb4qwOcGiNrQM3ptWvRmB4JtpaTFgFVlWLXNOQ6c/edit



Explainer:

https://arichiv.github.io/saa-non-cookie-storage/omit-unpartitioned-cookies.html



Bug: 1484966

entry.title: Fixing crash in BackForwardMenuModel due to navigation when menu is open
entry.content:
There have been numerous crashes in BackForwardMenuModel. These all seem

to have the same root cause. There are cases where navigation could

happen when the menu is open and this causes the index to be out of sync

and this could trigger CHECK or DCHECK failures in code. The fix

attempts to observe navigation on the active web content when the menu

is open and notifies the delegate about the menu changes which results

in keeping things in sync.



Bug: 1516574, 1351386

entry.title: [A11y] Do not rely on state propagation for aria-hidden changes
entry.content:
In CL:5169706, the implementation for aria-hidden changes was changed

to use a new propagation mechanism (OnInheritedCachedValuesChanged()) that can propagate cached states downward in a subtree.



However, aria-hidden changes can also result in changes to the validity

of aria-owns (as aria-hidden objects

do not support aria-owns), and aria-owns can affect parts of the tree

that are not strictly descendants.



The previous implementation addressed this

better, by simply wiping out the subtree with the aria-hidden change.



Fixed: 1518333

Change-Id: If88bff798f7098b1847a9277d0e92a00eddaf27a

entry.title: [CSC] Fix the killswitch
entry.content:
Use a base::Feature killswitch that is distinct from the one

auto-generated to go with the OT token. Use the killswitch

to gracefully reject Captured Surface Control API calls

coming from an OT-enabled site if the killswitch is engaged.



Prior to this change, OT users who did not manually enable

the CapturedSurfaceControl base::Feature ran into

a render process crash (through a BadMessage).

entry.title: [PM] Make WebContentsProxy a simple WeakPtr<WebContents> wrapper
entry.content:
This removes some complexity from PerformanceManagerTabHelper that's

no longer needed.



* Remove ResourceCoordinatorSignalObserver::GetContentsForDispatch,

which has no callers.

* Remove WebContentsProxy::LastNavigationId and

WebContentsProxy::LastNewDocNavigationId, which have no callers

except GetContentsForDispatch.

* Since PerformanceManagerTabHelper no longer needs to implement

LastNavigationId and LastNewDocNavigationId, it no longer needs to

be a WebContentsProxyImpl and pass WebContentsProxy a WeakPtr to

itself. Instead it can pass WebContentsProxy a WeakPtr to the

WebContents.

entry.title: Treat layers with duplicated IDs as invalid.
entry.content:
We do not expect duplicated IDs from the server. However, layer IDs being unique is a useful assumption for limited entropy randomization.



This CL provides an implementation that will discard any layer from the seed if its ID is not unique, and emit an enum histogram. For example, a seed may have {layer_id:101, layer_id:101, layer_id:999}. With this CL, only the layer with ID 999 will be valid. This means any study referencing the layers with ID 101 is not going to be assigned (see study_filtering.cc, ShouldAddStudy()).



Bug: b/319690282

entry.title: Remove the DCHECK for directly composited image tiling size and layer bounds
entry.content:
Floating point error may cause the difference between scaled tiling

size and layer bounds to be slightly larger than the epsion (==1).

We could increase the epsilon to tolerate errors, but I'm changing

how we calculate tiling rect, which will make the check invalid.

entry.title: viz: Accumulate embedder transform when calculating overlay damage index
entry.content:
SurfaceAggregator has a check to not assign an overlay damage index to a

quad if it is smaller than the surface damage (in which case we cannot

confidently say that the damage is attributable to the quad). This

check transforms the quad rect to the closest compositor frame root and

compares it with a surface damage rect. If the closest compositor frame

root is not the overall root, these rects may end up in different

coordinate spaces.



This CL appends the transform to the true root for the quad rect so the

comparison is done in root space. This is not an issue currently since

we don't observe the overlay damage index for quads in non-root passes,

but will be needed for partially delegated compositing on Windows.



Bug: 1132392

Change-Id: Idb697c7ef024029d92c048f7b7b77c6809e151d7

entry.title: Revert "Move filling timestamp from FillingContext to FormStructure"
entry.content:
This reverts commit a6c255be62c3c443f3f93f2f689e48bfe902f0a9.



Reason for revert: possible culprit of build failures crbug.com/1521832



Original change's description:

> Move filling timestamp from FillingContext to FormStructure

>

> We are targeting renaming FillingContext to RefillContext, as it is

> mainly used for refills and not every "filling" related information is

> stored in it.

>

> One thing that is used outside of refills is the filling time. This CL

> moves it out of the struct and into FormStructure.

>

> This CL also modifies the nature of the variable from `original`

> filling time to `last` filling time, as this would be more appropriate

> with its usage.

>

> The CL also records it for field by field filling, which initially did

> not set it.

>

entry.title: WebUI: Enforce querySelector<Type>() pattern via ESLint, part 2.
entry.content:
A common misuse of querySelector/querySelectorAll is to use a type cast,

like

this.shadowRoot.querySelector(...) as Type



instead of leveraging the type parameter, like

this.shadowRoot.querySelector(...)



In this part fixing several violations in ash/webui/ code. The goal is

to enable ESLint no-restricted-syntax checks to catch these by default

in upcoming CLs.

entry.title: [AsyncSB] Add interstitial histograms for async checks
entry.content:
We'd like to know how long the user sees the page before seeing the

warning as well as whether it affects the warning bypass rate.



This CL includes the following changes to achieve it:

* Log when the navigation is committed in AsyncCheckTracker.

* Add an optional blocked_page_shown_timestamp field in

MetricsHelper::ReportDetails and log the histograms based on the

value.

* Inject blocked_page_shown_timestamp when Safe Browsing blocking

page is created. If it is created in a navigation throttle, it

is set to nullopt because the page is never shown. Otherwise, we

will get the timestamp from AsyncCheckTracker (see the change in

BaseUIManager::DisplayBlockingPage).

* Log the delay histogram when an interstitial is shown in

SecurityInterstitialTabHelper::DidFinishNavigation.



Side note: It is hard to get the exact time when the warning is

displayed on user's screen, so we use the time when

DidFinishNavigation is called as a "proxy" for when the warning is

displayed. We only need the relative "delay" between the page and the

interstitial, so this approach should work.



Histograms added:

interstitial.{SecurityInterstitialSBType}decision{RepeatVisit}{IsPostCommitInterstitialSuffix}

(e.g. interstitial.phishing.decision.after_page_shown)

interstitial.{SecurityInterstitialSBType}interaction{IsPostCommitInterstitialSuffix}

(e.g. interstitial.phishing.interaction.after_page_shown)

interstitial.{SecurityInterstitialSBType}show_delay{SecurityInterstitialSBWithSourceType}

(e.g. interstitial.phishing.show_delay.from_real_time_check)

entry.title: Sort DNS results after each transaction
entry.content:
Only done if a new kUseHostResolverCache experiment is enabled. If

using the new cache, which separately caches results for each DNS

transaction, need to sort results for each transaction instead of only

sorting all results together after the completion of all transactions.



When doing the transaction-separate sort, no sort is done on the final

merged results. This is a slight behavior change as it ends up meaning

IPv4 and IPv6 results are separately sorted and all IPv6 always placed

before all IPv4 in the final results, but this shouldn't have any real

results in practice since the connection code is now separating them

and ignoring the inter-family order anyway.



Another minor change is that the old merged sort only did any sorting

when results contained at least one IPv6 address, but the transaction-

separate sort is always done as long as the transaction has at least

one result. This is mostly a simplification, but we also can no longer

use IPv6 presence to decide on whether or not to sort IPv4 because we

don't necessarily know if we'll have AAAA results when A results are

ready.



Also, turned out that we didn't have any HostResolver tests verifying

that AddressSorter was used at all, so a big portion of this CL ended up

being adding those tests for both with and without the new experiment

enabled.

that already has a current default (this will be used to set the

synchronously).

- Setting the current default SequencedTaskRunner to a new value in

a scope that already has a current default (this will be used to

set the current default SequencedTaskRunner to the one on which

RunOrPostTask was called when running a task synchronously).

entry.title: Add support for allowing elements with display:contents to be focused.
entry.content:
Chromestatus: https://chromestatus.com/feature/6237396851228672



This lands support for allowing elements with display:contents to be

focused, behind a feature flag that is created with status:experimental.



This is as concluded (though without a group resolution) in

https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/2632 and as discussed a bit

in https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/1837 and proposed in

https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9425 . Note that this diverges from

Gecko (see https://bugzil.la/1553549, https://bugzil.la/1791648, and

https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/772) and WebKit

(see https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=255149 and

https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/164).



This makes the element focusable when it has a tabindex. Note

that this does not match Gecko and WebKit, which also require that its

'display' value is changed (away from 'contents') to make it focusable.



Note that the element is still not tabbable in Chrome; this is

https://crbug.com/1428419. This also does not match Gecko and WebKit,

where it is tabbable whenever it is focusable. The added test

slot-element-tabbable.tentative.html fails both tests as a result, but

is added anyway. (Gecko and WebKit pass the display: block test but

fail the default style (display: contents) test.)



The added tests display-contents-focusable-001.html and

slot-element-focusable.tentative.html are partly fixed by this change,

but the style part is still broken due to https://crbug.com/1428420.



Bug: 1366037

Bug: 1428419, 1428420

Change-Id: I46a8ad3b6442ce07f440c8f6a07210bac305600e
